qas.question: Who thought Burke's trial of Hastings was a moral foundation of the British Empire?
What did Burke think the British Empire should be governed based on?
What did Burke call 'a smuggling adventure'?
What did Burke think had disgraced Britain in India?
What historian laid the foundations for the morals of the British Empire?
What did Burke say the plan of freedom must be governed by?
What did Burke say had disgraced India in Britain?
What did Burke nickname his paternalistic doctrine?
What kind of doctrine did Hastings propose?

context: The historian <a0_0><b4_0>Piers Brendon<b4_0/><a0_0/> asserts that Burke laid the moral foundations for the British Empire, epitomised in the trial of Warren Hastings, that was ultimately to be its undoing: when Burke stated that "<b5_0>The British Empire<b5_0/> must be governed on <a1_0>a plan of freedom<a1_0/>, for it will be governed by no other", this was "...an ideological bacillus that would prove fatal. This was Edmund Burke's <b8_0>paternalistic<b8_0/> doctrine that colonial government was a trust. It was to be so exercised for the benefit of subject people that they would eventually attain their birthright—freedom". As a consequence of this opinion, Burke objected to <b6_0>the <a2_0><a3_0>opium trade<b6_0/><a3_0/><a2_0/>, which he called a "<b7_0>smuggling adventure<b7_0/>" and condemned "the great Disgrace of the British character in India".
